Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observers: DM, GF Site: Wx Plot, BTL, Open to sky, good wind protection HS: 230cm

Snowpack is 300mm at this location with only the top 150cm observed. General concern at 50cm down on ice crust with new load coming as well as numerous ice crusts from 102cm through 117cm. Stability test did not show a significant hazard in this area however. Observer noted that new snow appears to be bonding better to the 50cm crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit dug in a Ski Area
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Fog was dipping up and down at this elevation throughout the tour. No surface weakening observed despite the consistent cold temps. Surface hoar observed under the spruces lower down where the moisture seemed to be trapped by the forest canopy. The ski surface wasn't recrystallized grains but settled boot-top powder capped by a very minor wind/rime skin. Skiing was good while in the open, conditions seemed stable. Aspects that tip west looked to be more wind effected.
Weak layer at 91-93 seems to be the low density snow on the surface just before new years that became the slightest bit faceted.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Intention for full profile was to determine the size of wind loading on NE aspect after 2020/01/04 wind event. Also to locate a possible PWL to detemrine if a wind slab could step down and trigger a PWL. At the current time, sky, wind, and precip were low, however, by end of pit profile, all picked up. Pit in an open area with a rock and grass bottom.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Though no obvious signs of avalanche danger or instabilities were observed today, buried surface hoar layers were found in the snowpack on protected north facing terrain near and below treeline on Left Peak. Currently, these layers pose little hazard due to the fact that the snowpack is shallow and good anchoring exist in the area. However, this is something to monitor if we get a significant amount of snow in the near future.

Pit dug outside gate 6 at the top of Endless Couloir in GTNP. Most active layer was suspected buried surface hoar at 80cm, however in the event of a slide this could easily step down to the basal facets, which are large but showing signs of rounding. We traversed back inbounds to descend. Patrollers involved: T. Babcock, T. Stavn, B. Griffith.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snow pit at Alpine WS for ground truth of radars installed at the weather station. No stability tests done.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Identifiera drevsnö i Sz och bedöma hur reaktiv det är.
Sz på Lill Skarven som har ännu inte fyllt i helt. Ytan är inte slät ännu och vissa stenar syns fortfarande. I nuläge är Sz lite på grund av varierande snömängder.
Previous wind loading noted from SE and current wind loading from NW

- Profile objectives: check HS in an alpine start zone and assess for presence of any deeper weak layers (SH, MFcr). - Site characteristics: upper part of a heavily cross-loaded bowl feature. - Did not observe below 160. - Periods of strong NW gusts and moderate blowing during the profile. - Crystal form of SP test result at 180 difficult to assess due to wind and blowing snow. PPgp was obvious to the eye. Could not get this result to repeat. - Denisty decreased approximately 70cm above ground. The bottom 25cms was significantly softer (likely mature basal FC/DH). - A size 1.5 Sa soft slab (F+) was triggered on a convex roll below the profile site. No Na activity observed in the zone.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug at top of second gully busy back country today. Good skiing, poor structure, moderate strength, low energy. Rain crust in snow pack supportive but faceting on top deserves monitoring. Storm cycle around 80 cm in several days.

Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Several pits dug along route

Overall this snowpack seemed very soft and less supportable than in other locations. 1 meter seems a bit shallow and it fellt like this would be a more likely place to trigger a large avalanche than in areas where the snowpack is harder and deeper.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: There wasn't much of a slab to perform any stability tests. The most interesting layer was the chained 1mm facets sandwiched between a rimed MF crust above and a very stout crust below.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We were in a location that may have experienced an avalanche previously, causing basal facets to be more affected by the rain during the 12/19-12/21 storm cycle. We dug to the ground, which was very brushy. The ECT test did not slide freely when it broke at the ground (I would consider shear quality to be Q2 because of this.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We dug 1/4 of the way up the bootpack on the climbers left side of the face. This pit was the most encouraging of the three we dug yesterday, and we continued up to the top after completing our pit to ski off the backside. This snowpack appeared to be the most homogeneous of any pit I have dug this season. There were a few layers identified by CT scores; however, no signs of propagation, no SH that we were able to identify, and no "shit sandwich" of crust/facet combo layers towards the base of the snowpack. The layer of concern I have at 50 cms from the base. while there is no crust facet combo i was able to leverage the ect block on a shear Q2 at that layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Layer of Concern: Nov 18 Rain Crust at 70cm. CTH21(SP), CTN (but SP on 31st tap), ECTX (propagated when snow removed to 85cm and gave hard tap).

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Assessment of 191123 MFcr/FC Combo Open Bowl at treeline.

- Site characteristics: Open bowl with planar scree slope. Pit location just below ridge top. - Profile objectives: Assess for presence of mid Dec. SH and state of Nov.23 MFcr. - Nov.23 MFcr down 59; fairly decomposed. No reactivity with two CT and two ST tests. - Wind was light, variable.
Wind-sheltered, densely-treed slope.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skier Triggered Avalanche on 12/23/2019. Still reactive on Basal facets and buried surface hoar...shallow and rocky...ECT failed to propigate cause it failed at the ground/rocks/basal facets first but the buried surface hoar is still able to be triggered moderately to difficult, but still potential to propigate. Shallow weak rocky snowpack.

Observers DB, GB Site: Standard study plot location. BTL clearing.
DT targeting Dec11 SH prod DTM16(SC) in Nov12 FC

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This test slope location is deep and may not be completelty representative of HS throughout the basin. It does provide a good example of a deep strong slab with old October snow continuing to strengthen and round. It would take a massive load to break this slab and create an avalanche.
